data.title: John Fahey & Stanley Kubrick: The secret connection
data.text:
Last night I went to the local rep cinema to catch Stanley Kubrick's 1971

film "Clockwork Orange", which film buffs will know has been out of

circulation for many years due to a rights dispute and was recently

re-released. I think it must be at least 25 years since I last saw it. I

won't go into an OT commentary on the film, but there is one brief shot

which might be of interest to fans of the late John Fahey: About 25(?)

minutes into the film there is a scene in which Alex, the central character

(played wonderfully by Malcolm McDowell) and supreme Beethoven admirer,

strolls through a 70's-futuristic shopping mall and stops at a small record

shop. Several LP covers are visibly on display, of which I recognized three

(it was a lousy print, but even so they would be even harder to spot on a

video I think): Walter/Wendy Carlo's album of Moog music from "2001: A Space

Odyssey" (A little Kubrickian logrolling there); an album by the now-obscure

Keef Hartley Band; and, amazingly, a copy of John Fahey's "The

Transfiguration of Blind Joe Death"! The lettering was not legible-- at

least in this faded print-- but the cover design was unmistakble.

So there you have it. Was Kubrick a Fahey fan, or was it some unknown

set-dresser? Was this mere coincidence, or was someone paying a little

tribute? When you consider all the thousands of LPs that *could* have been

on display, and what a control freak Kubrick apparently was, it's tempting

to conclude the latter. I wonder if Fahey knew about this (and did he care)?

I wonder if his music might ever have been considered for use in a Kubrick

film? I suppose we'll never know...

the central character

> (played wonderfully by Malcolm McDowell) and supreme Beethoven admirer,

> strolls through a 70's-futuristic shopping mall and stops at a small record

> shop.

The Chelsea Drugstore.

Several LP covers are visibly on display, of which I recognized three

> (it was a lousy print, but even so they would be even harder to spot on a

> video I think): Walter/Wendy Carlo's album of Moog music from "2001: A Space

> Odyssey"

Walter Carlos did NOT compose the 2001 soundtrack.

> So there you have it. Was Kubrick a Fahey fan, or was it some unknown

> set-dresser?

I asked Kubrick's daughter about it, you can find it on my site.

Viddy Well!

Alex Thrawn

www.maloclmmcdowell.net

----------

Oh, gosh, and here for nearly 34 years-- since I first saw the film, in

fact-- I always thought Walter/Wendy Carlos also composed under the names of

Richard Strauss, Johann Strauss, and Gyorgy Ligeti. Silly me. Thanks so much

for seting me straight about who really wrote the "Blue Danube".

I was referring to an album of Moog arrangements of music from 2001 which

was around in the late 60s. Hell, maybe it wasn't Carlos; I haven't seen a

copy in 30 years, but there it is in the film. Give me credit for having

half a brain, will you? Like, duh.

Here's what I found on that site:

The Chelsea Drugstore is where the Music Bootik scene was filmed in ACO (he

pics up the two devotchkas there). I wondered

if that was how the place actually looked and asked Stanley Kubrick's

daughter Katharina who had a walk on part in that scene.

K: "As I recall, The Chelsea drugstore looked pretty much like that. The

obvious placement of the 2001 album was "set dressing" and I'm

sure that Dad had things moved around the place to suit his needs. Overall

though it had exactly that feel to it. It was a totally cool place as

far as my 16 year old self was

concerned."

All the best,

Steve Comeau
